text:
What was the elevator
pitch in those first days?

How would you have described it
in two or three sentences
to somebody, what the vision was?
We had a mantra somewhere.

It was that the strength 
is in the numbers.
What we meant by that is - first,
let me say that with the change into

allowing Blacks into
the mainstream economy now,

what quickly happened
and very soon was that

white men were 
comfortable with Black men now.
They could talk business.
They could do all these things.

Both sets of men, 
both white men and

Black men somehow 
could not find it comfortable

to talk to women about 
including them in business.
And this is a worldwide
phenomenon.

John, I'm sure you would 
agree that the women issue

and into the mainstream economy 
is now not a South African issue.
It is a worldwide issue.

So when we then
decided to do WIPHOLD,
we did two things.

One, we're going to concentrate on
forcing women into the mainstream economy.
And two, in our case,

it's going to be both 
Black and white women,
because we are in the same position
in this kind of space.
